trans-unit.source: Authenticating Service Management Requests
trans-unit.target: Authenticating Service Management Requests

trans-unit.source: Requests to the management service must be authenticated using one of the following methods:
trans-unit.target: Requests to the management service must be authenticated using one of the following methods:

trans-unit.source: Authenticate using Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Authenticate using Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Secure requests to the management service can be authenticated by creating an Azure AD application and using the <languageKeyword>Active Directory Authentication Library</languageKeyword> to obtain an access token from the application.
trans-unit.target: Secure requests to the management service can be authenticated by creating an Azure AD application and using the <languageKeyword>Active Directory Authentication Library</languageKeyword> to obtain an access token from the application.

trans-unit.source: For more information about authentication using Azure AD, see <externalLink><linkText>Authentication Scenarios for Azure AD</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn499820.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about authentication using Azure AD, see <externalLink><linkText>Authentication Scenarios for Azure AD</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn499820.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Do the following to add an application to Azure AD:
trans-unit.target: Do the following to add an application to Azure AD:

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Towards the bottom of the left menu, click <ui>Active Directory</ui>, and then click <ui>Default Directory</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Towards the bottom of the left menu, click <ui>Active Directory</ui>, and then click <ui>Default Directory</ui>.

trans-unit.source: On the Default Directory page, under <ui>Integrate applications</ui>, click <ui>Add an application you’re developing</ui>.
trans-unit.target: On the Default Directory page, under <ui>Integrate applications</ui>, click <ui>Add an application you’re developing</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the application, select <ui>NATIVE CLIENT APPLICATION</ui>, and then click the right arrow.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the application, select <ui>NATIVE CLIENT APPLICATION</ui>, and then click the right arrow.

trans-unit.source: Enter a URI for the application and then click the checkmark.
trans-unit.target: Enter a URI for the application and then click the checkmark.

trans-unit.source: The URI includes the name of the application that is preceded by <languageKeyword>http://localhost/</languageKeyword>.
trans-unit.target: The URI includes the name of the application that is preceded by <languageKeyword>http://localhost/</languageKeyword>.

trans-unit.source: After the application is created, you must add permission for the application to access the Service Management APIs.
trans-unit.target: After the application is created, you must add permission for the application to access the Service Management APIs.

trans-unit.source: Go to the page for your application, and then click <ui>Configure</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Go to the page for your application, and then click <ui>Configure</ui>.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Permissions to other applications</ui> section at the bottom of the configuration page, click <ui>Select application</ui>, and then select <ui>Windows Azure Service Management API</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Permissions to other applications</ui> section at the bottom of the configuration page, click <ui>Select application</ui>, and then select <ui>Windows Azure Service Management API</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Delegated Permissions: 0</ui>, and then select <ui>Access Azure Service Management</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Delegated Permissions: 0</ui>, and then select <ui>Access Azure Service Management</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Click <ui>Save</ui> on the bottom menu.
trans-unit.target: Click <ui>Save</ui> on the bottom menu.

trans-unit.source: You can easily install the <languageKeyword>Active Directory Authentication Library</languageKeyword> into your Visual Studio project by using the NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: You can easily install the <languageKeyword>Active Directory Authentication Library</languageKeyword> into your Visual Studio project by using the NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: To install the package, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To install the package, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click <ui>Manage NuGet Packages</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click <ui>Manage NuGet Packages</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Type <languageKeyword>Active Directory</languageKeyword> in the search box, click <ui>Install</ui> for the <ui>Active Directory Authentication Library</ui> package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type <languageKeyword>Active Directory</languageKeyword> in the search box, click <ui>Install</ui> for the <ui>Active Directory Authentication Library</ui> package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: The following code example shows how to retrieve the access token:
trans-unit.target: The following code example shows how to retrieve the access token:

trans-unit.source: When you use the code listed above, you need to replace the following:
trans-unit.target: When you use the code listed above, you need to replace the following:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>{tenantId}</embeddedLabel> with the GUID of the application.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>{tenantId}</embeddedLabel> with the GUID of the application.

trans-unit.source: To find the GUID, go to the Default Directory page in the Active Directory section of the Management Portal, select the application that you previously created, and then click <ui>View Endpoints</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To find the GUID, go to the Default Directory page in the Active Directory section of the Management Portal, select the application that you previously created, and then click <ui>View Endpoints</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Copy the GUID of the application and replace the placeholder with it.
trans-unit.target: Copy the GUID of the application and replace the placeholder with it.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>{clientId}</embeddedLabel> with the client identifier.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>{clientId}</embeddedLabel> with the client identifier.

trans-unit.source: To find the client identifier, go to the Configuration page of the application in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To find the client identifier, go to the Configuration page of the application in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>{redirectUri}</embeddedLabel> with the redirect Uri.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>{redirectUri}</embeddedLabel> with the redirect Uri.

trans-unit.source: To find the redirect Uri, go to the Configuration page of the application in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To find the redirect Uri, go to the Configuration page of the application in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Authenticate using a management certificate
trans-unit.target: Authenticate using a management certificate

trans-unit.source: Secure requests to the management service can be authenticated by using management certificates over SSL.
trans-unit.target: Secure requests to the management service can be authenticated by using management certificates over SSL.

trans-unit.source: To use a management certificate, it must be uploaded to Azure.
trans-unit.target: To use a management certificate, it must be uploaded to Azure.

trans-unit.source: After you add a management certificate to the subscription, you can sign the requests to the service by using the certificate.
trans-unit.target: After you add a management certificate to the subscription, you can sign the requests to the service by using the certificate.

trans-unit.source: For information about creating management certificates and associating them with a subscription, see <legacyLink xlink:href="74bd1e62-497f-44ec-a97f-9ed79d18e859" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: For information about creating management certificates and associating them with a subscription, see <legacyLink xlink:href="74bd1e62-497f-44ec-a97f-9ed79d18e859" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: When designing an application, keep the following points about management certificates in mind:
trans-unit.target: When designing an application, keep the following points about management certificates in mind:

trans-unit.source: The Service Management API does not verify that a certificate is still valid.
trans-unit.target: The Service Management API does not verify that a certificate is still valid.

trans-unit.source: Authentication will succeed against an expired certificate.
trans-unit.target: Authentication will succeed against an expired certificate.

trans-unit.source: All management certificates carry the same set of privileges.
trans-unit.target: All management certificates carry the same set of privileges.

trans-unit.source: There is no notion of “role-based” authentication where one management certificate can be configured in one role and another on the same subscription is configured in a different role.
trans-unit.target: There is no notion of “role-based” authentication where one management certificate can be configured in one role and another on the same subscription is configured in a different role.

trans-unit.target: <languageKeyword>Thumbprint</languageKeyword> represents the thumbprint if the management certificate that you added to the subscription.
